conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves upward, considering both position and size changes.
Object 1 is an apple casting shadow A.
Object 2 is a white flag or paper casting shadow B.
Object 3 is a transparent or translucent object (possibly glass) casting shadow C.
Object 4 is a curved object (appears to be a bone or similar item) casting shadow D.
When a light source moves upward, shadow size decreases and shadow position moves closer to being directly beneath the object.
Shadow A (apple) will become smaller in size and move closer to being directly beneath the apple when the light source moves upward.
Shadow B (flag/paper) will become smaller in size and move closer to being directly beneath the flag/paper when the light source moves upward.
Shadow C (transparent object) will become smaller in size, move closer to being directly beneath the transparent object, and may become even more diffuse/faint when the light source moves upward.
Shadow D (curved object) will become smaller in size, move closer to being directly beneath the curved object, and maintain its curved shape with less distortion when the light source moves upward.

When the light source moves upward, all shadows (A, B, C, D) will become smaller in size, move inward closer to being directly beneath their respective objects, and maintain their overall shape with less distortion/elongation.
The translucent object's shadow (C) may appear even more diffuse as the light source moves upward.
As the light source moves higher, the angle at which light rays hit the objects becomes more vertical, causing the shadows to contract toward the base of each object.
